Award.AwardTitle: Kinetically Viable Pathways for Multitopic DCC
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Jeffrey S. Moore of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign is developing chemistry to synthesize new, shape-persistent, carbon-based cage molecules. He is investigating methods to link small precursor molecules into larger, hollow cage-like structures. Knowledge obtained from this project will directly impact the design and synthesis of important carbon-based materials. In addition, the three-dimensional structures contain voids on the order of a few nanometers in length and with persistent shapes, so these structures may sequester other small molecules. Professor Moore and his research group continue to participate in several mentoring and outreach activities to communicate the importance of scientific advances to K-12 audiences and the general public. They are involved in specific programs such as Encouraging Tomorrow's Chemists (ETC) and the Illinois Female Engineers in Academia Training (iFEAT).

Professor Moore is exploring synthetic methods to construct cage molecules with defined cavities for host-guest interactions, adsorption, separation, and stabilization of reactive intermediates. The typical approach in this field is to use a heuristic, structure-focused strategy and design precursors with the appropriate geometry required for a targeted structure. However, this method frequently fails to produce the desired outcome, or yields no discernable products. In this project, Professor Moore is developing experimental methods to probe dynamic covalent chemistry (DCC) energy landscapes and to use that information in formulating strategies to direct DCC precursors along kinetically viable pathways while avoiding undesirable kinetic traps. The particular DCC method being used is alkyne metathesis, and the specific issues being addressed include how kinetic traps affect the outcome of multitopic DCC, what design strategies will direct DCC along kinetically viable pathways, and how strategies used to construct 2-dimensional structures can be adapted to the synthesis of 3-dimensional cages. Knowledge gained from this project is expected to relate directly towards the construction of other important classes of materials such as covalent organic frameworks (COFs).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cycloparaphenyleneacetylenes via AM

The Moore Group has reported an efficient synthetic route to cycloparaphenyleneacetylene (CPPA) macrocycles via alkyne metathesis (AM) in high yields. Subjecting a ditopic precursor with rigid geometry to AM afforded the CPPA macrocyclic precursor in quantitative yields at gram-scale. Reductive aromatization of this precursor afforded a fully conjugated CPPA, [3]CPP3A, in high yields. It was discovered that [3]CPP3A could bind C70 with a large association constant of 105M-1 in organic solvents. Additionally, the ring strain of [3]CPP3A enabled the copper-free click reaction on each acetylene moiety in a total combined yield of 82%. This is the first example of three successive strain-promoted azide-alkyne cycloaddition reactions.

 

Kinetically Trapped Tetrahedral Cages via AM

During the final months of NSF-CHE 1300313 (i.e., the award that predated NSF-CHE 16-10328), the Moore Group discovered a 3D tetrahedral organic cage as a kinetic product from DC synthesis. The organic cage, TdA, was synthesized in near quantitative yields on the multigram scale from a tritopic precursor. Characterization by single crystal X-ray diffraction demonstrated the tetrahedral geometry of the TdA cage. To test the kinetic stability of TdA within the reaction conditions, mixing experiments were performed between two cage precursors and two tetrahedral cages under similar AM conditions. The mixing experiment between two precursors with similar geometry but different solubilizing groups afforded a product distribution of mixed cage species. The mixing experiment involving two tetrahedral cages having different solubilizing groups afforded only TdA and TdB with no indication of vertex mixing. These results allowed us to conclude that the tetrahedral cage, once formed, becomes kinetically trapped under the reaction conditions used.

 

A Putative Kinetic Bottleneck in Multitopic AM

In the dynamic synthesis of molecular cages via DCC, the typical approach involves heuristic methods of discovery where only structural enthalpies of desired targets are considered. In our experience with AM, this approach often fails to produce the desired outcome or yields no discernible products at all. In a practical sense, these circumstances arise due to finite catalyst lifetimes, slow rates of reactions, and potential kinetic bottlenecks in DCC reactions that retard or prevent equilibration. Rational precursor design principles are needed to accelerate discovery in molecular cage synthesis via DCC. Toward this end, the Moore Group performed a systematic study investigating the effects of precursor bite angle (the angle between phenylene edges) on cage formation via AM and made the surprising observation that precursors possessing the target’s ideal vertex geometry (60°) do not provide the best outcome. Specifically, the oxygen-containing precursor has a bite   angle that is better matched to the ideal tetrahedron than the carbon- or   sulfur-containing precursor. However, the highest yields are observed for the    carbon-containing precursor. This work supports the argument that enthalpic considerations alone are insufficient to describe the experimental observations from DCC reactions.

 

Molecular Shape Persistence of Cages Correlates to Solid State Porosity

Recently, porous solids constructed from discrete molecular cages have garnered much interest due to their ease of handling and solubility. While much research in this field has focused on synthesizing novel cages, fewer studies have investigated the relationship between molecular structure and macroscopic properties in molecular cage systems. Since molecular cages possess pore apertures resembling the size of small gas molecules (< 2 nm), cage motion greatly affects the overall porosity of these materials. Toward this end, the Moore Group performed a systematic study of the effects of molecular cage shape-persistence on the porosity of molecular cage solids. By synthesizing three molecular cages with varying degrees of shape-persistence, constructing molecular solids from each cage, and experimentally measuring the surface area for each solid, we discovered that porosity correlates with shape-persistence of molecular cages. Investigating cage motion via molecular dynamics simulations provided a molecular-scale understanding of how bond flexibility affects porosity of molecular cages and supported our experimental observations.

 

Rule-based modeling of escape from an [n]-rung ladder

         We are currently developing a rule-based computational model to understand the reaction pathway for escape from an [n]-rung molecular ladder based on kinetic perturbations of various species in a generic DCC reaction. This model will provide us with a better understand of the kinetic properties that control error correction in a system under equilibrium. With such an understanding, we can plan for precise access of complex molecular architectures with a synthetic strategy that avoids unproductive or deleterious kinetic traps. Synthetically we are validating our model by synthesizing ladder precursors with individual activated rungs and studying their kinetic self-assembly in alkyne metathesis. We have found this strategy to be successful for circumventing kinetic traps. Further studies are ongoing.


Last Modified: 12/05/2019
Modified by: Jeffrey S Moore
